highlights.text: Venkat tries to argue that written text is all you need to create 'personhood'
That feels very much like redefining personhood to me
We don't have the language to talk about our new relationships to language models
They are a new kind of otherness
We grant rivers and mountains 'personhood' in order to legally protect them from harm
Many rivers, mountains, and nature reserves have been given legal personhood
In 2014, the Te Urewera park, the ancestral home of the Tuhoe people, became the first natural feature in the country to be recognised as a legal person

In 2018, Mount Taranaki 
 was awarded the same status
Granting rivers legal personhood represents a seismic shift from the bedrock belief in Western society that humans are at the apex of the natural world
Metaphors profoundly influence how we understand
We're having trouble framing and understanding AI systems
AI insiders refer to language models as 'aliens'
'Alien' is the most common description people are using for AI systems
By alien we're trying to say 'otherness' or 'thing we can be in relationship with'
We can have a relationship with a river or a hummingbird
We have always struggled to understand non-human beings
We should be making plant and animal AIs
Humans level is not an AI level we can make
